segment.source: Networking for games
segment.target: Networking for games

segment.source: Learn how to develop and incorporate networking features into your DirectX game.
segment.target: Learn how to develop and incorporate networking features into your DirectX game.

segment.source: Networking for games
segment.target: Networking for games

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Learn how to develop and incorporate networking features into your DirectX game.
segment.target: Learn how to develop and incorporate networking features into your DirectX game.

segment.source: Concepts at a glance
segment.target: Concepts at a glance

segment.source: A variety of networking features can be used in your DirectX game, whether it is a simple standalone game to massively multi-player games.
segment.target: A variety of networking features can be used in your DirectX game, whether it is a simple standalone game to massively multi-player games.

segment.source: The simplest use of networking would be to store user names and game scores on a central network server.
segment.target: The simplest use of networking would be to store user names and game scores on a central network server.

segment.source: Networking APIs are needed in multi-player games that use the infrastructure (client-server or internet peer-to-peer) model and also by ad hoc (local peer-to-peer) games.
segment.target: Networking APIs are needed in multi-player games that use the infrastructure (client-server or internet peer-to-peer) model and also by ad hoc (local peer-to-peer) games.

segment.source: For server-based multi-player games, a central game server usually handles most of the game operations and the client game app is used for input, displaying graphics, playing audio, and other features.
segment.target: For server-based multi-player games, a central game server usually handles most of the game operations and the client game app is used for input, displaying graphics, playing audio, and other features.

segment.source: The speed and latency of network transfers is a concern for a satisfactory game experience.
segment.target: The speed and latency of network transfers is a concern for a satisfactory game experience.

segment.source: For peer-to-peer games, each player's app handles the input and graphics.
segment.target: For peer-to-peer games, each player's app handles the input and graphics.

segment.source: In most cases, the game players are located in close proximity so that network latency should be lower but is still a concern.
segment.target: In most cases, the game players are located in close proximity so that network latency should be lower but is still a concern.

segment.source: How to discovery peers and establish a connection becomes a concern.
segment.target: How to discovery peers and establish a connection becomes a concern.

segment.source: For single-player games, a central Web server or service is often used to store user names, game scores, and other miscellaneous information.
segment.target: For single-player games, a central Web server or service is often used to store user names, game scores, and other miscellaneous information.

segment.source: In these games, the speed and latency of networking transfers is less of a concern since it doesn't directly affect game operation.
segment.target: In these games, the speed and latency of networking transfers is less of a concern since it doesn't directly affect game operation.

segment.source: Network conditions can change at any time, so any game that uses networking APIs needs to handle network exceptions that may occur.
segment.target: Network conditions can change at any time, so any game that uses networking APIs needs to handle network exceptions that may occur.

segment.source: To learn more about handling network exceptions, see Networking basics.
segment.target: To learn more about handling network exceptions, see Networking basics.

segment.source: Firewalls and web proxies are common and can affect the ability to use networking features.
segment.target: Firewalls and web proxies are common and can affect the ability to use networking features.

segment.source: A game that uses networking needs to be prepared to properly handle firewalls and proxies.
segment.target: A game that uses networking needs to be prepared to properly handle firewalls and proxies.

segment.source: For mobile devices, it is important to monitor available network resources and behave accordingly when on metered networks where roaming or data costs can be significant.
segment.target: For mobile devices, it is important to monitor available network resources and behave accordingly when on metered networks where roaming or data costs can be significant.

segment.source: Network isolation is part of the app security model used by Windows.
segment.target: Network isolation is part of the app security model used by Windows.

segment.source: Windows actively discovers network boundaries and enforces network access restrictions for network isolation.
segment.target: Windows actively discovers network boundaries and enforces network access restrictions for network isolation.

segment.source: Apps must declare network isolation capabilities in order to define the scope of network access.
segment.target: Apps must declare network isolation capabilities in order to define the scope of network access.

segment.source: Without declaring these capabilities, your app will not have access to network resources.
segment.target: Without declaring these capabilities, your app will not have access to network resources.

segment.source: To learn more about how Windows enforces network isolation for apps, see How to configure network isolation capabilities.
segment.target: To learn more about how Windows enforces network isolation for apps, see How to configure network isolation capabilities.

segment.source: Design considerations
segment.target: Design considerations

segment.source: A variety of networking APIs can be used in DirectX games.
segment.target: A variety of networking APIs can be used in DirectX games.

segment.source: So, it is important to pick the right API.
segment.target: So, it is important to pick the right API.

segment.source: Windows supports a variety of networking APIs that your app can use to communicate with other computers and devices over either the Internet or private networks.
segment.target: Windows supports a variety of networking APIs that your app can use to communicate with other computers and devices over either the Internet or private networks.

segment.source: Your first step is to figure out what networking features your app needs.
segment.target: Your first step is to figure out what networking features your app needs.

segment.source: The more popular network APIs for games include:
segment.target: The more popular network APIs for games include:

segment.source: TCP and sockets - Provides a reliable connection.
segment.target: TCP and sockets - Provides a reliable connection.

segment.source: Use TCP for game operations that don’t need security.
segment.target: Use TCP for game operations that don’t need security.

segment.source: TCP allows the server to easily scale, so it is commonly used in games that use the infrastructure (client-server or internet peer-to-peer) model.
segment.target: TCP allows the server to easily scale, so it is commonly used in games that use the infrastructure (client-server or internet peer-to-peer) model.

segment.source: TCP can also be used by ad hoc (local peer-to-peer) games over Wi-Fi Direct and Bluetooth.
segment.target: TCP can also be used by ad hoc (local peer-to-peer) games over Wi-Fi Direct and Bluetooth.

segment.source: TCP is commonly used for game object movement, character interaction, text chat, and other operations.
segment.target: TCP is commonly used for game object movement, character interaction, text chat, and other operations.

segment.source: The StreamSocket class provides a TCP socket that can be used in Windows Store games.
segment.target: The StreamSocket class provides a TCP socket that can be used in Windows Store games.

segment.source: The StreamSocket class is used with related classes in the Windows::Networking::Sockets namespace.
segment.target: The StreamSocket class is used with related classes in the Windows::Networking::Sockets namespace.

segment.source: TCP and sockets using SSL - Provides a reliable connection that prevents eavesdropping.
segment.target: TCP and sockets using SSL - Provides a reliable connection that prevents eavesdropping.

segment.source: Use TCP connections with SSL for game operations that need security.
segment.target: Use TCP connections with SSL for game operations that need security.

segment.source: The encryption and overhead of SSL adds a cost in latency and performance, so it is only used when security is needed.
segment.target: The encryption and overhead of SSL adds a cost in latency and performance, so it is only used when security is needed.

segment.source: TCP with SSL is commonly used for login, purchasing and trading assets, game character creation and management.
segment.target: TCP with SSL is commonly used for login, purchasing and trading assets, game character creation and management.

segment.source: The StreamSocket class provides a TCP socket that supports SSL.
segment.target: The StreamSocket class provides a TCP socket that supports SSL.

segment.source: UDP and sockets - Provides unreliable network transfers with low overhead.
segment.target: UDP and sockets - Provides unreliable network transfers with low overhead.

segment.source: UDP is used for game operations that require low latency and can tolerate some packet loss.
segment.target: UDP is used for game operations that require low latency and can tolerate some packet loss.

segment.source: This is often used for fighting games, shooting and tracers, network audio, and voice chat.
segment.target: This is often used for fighting games, shooting and tracers, network audio, and voice chat.

segment.source: The DatagramSocket class provides a UDP socket that can be used in Windows Store games.
segment.target: The DatagramSocket class provides a UDP socket that can be used in Windows Store games.

segment.source: The DatagramSocket class is used with related classes in the Windows::Networking::Sockets namespace.
segment.target: The DatagramSocket class is used with related classes in the Windows::Networking::Sockets namespace.

segment.source: HTTP Client - Provides a reliable connection to HTTP servers.
segment.target: HTTP Client - Provides a reliable connection to HTTP servers.

segment.source: The most common networking scenario is to access a web site to retrieve or store information.
segment.target: The most common networking scenario is to access a web site to retrieve or store information.

segment.source: A simple example would be a game that uses a website to store user information and game scores.
segment.target: A simple example would be a game that uses a website to store user information and game scores.

segment.source: When used with SSL for security, an HTTP client can be used for login, purchasing, trading assets, game character creation, and management.
segment.target: When used with SSL for security, an HTTP client can be used for login, purchasing, trading assets, game character creation, and management.

segment.source: The HttpClient class provides a modern HTTP client API for use in Windows Store games.
segment.target: The HttpClient class provides a modern HTTP client API for use in Windows Store games.

segment.source: The HttpClient class is used with related classes in the Windows::Web::Http namespace.
segment.target: The HttpClient class is used with related classes in the Windows::Web::Http namespace.

segment.source: Handling network exceptions in your DirectX game
segment.target: Handling network exceptions in your DirectX game

segment.source: When a network exception occurs in your DirectX game, this indicates a significant problem or failure.
segment.target: When a network exception occurs in your DirectX game, this indicates a significant problem or failure.

segment.source: Exceptions can occur for many reasons when using networking APIs.
segment.target: Exceptions can occur for many reasons when using networking APIs.

segment.source: Often, the exception can result from changes in network connectivity or other networking issues with the remote host or server.
segment.target: Often, the exception can result from changes in network connectivity or other networking issues with the remote host or server.

segment.source: Some causes of exceptions when using networking APIs include the following:
segment.target: Some causes of exceptions when using networking APIs include the following:

segment.source: Input from the user for a hostname or a URI contains errors and is not valid.
segment.target: Input from the user for a hostname or a URI contains errors and is not valid.

segment.source: Name resolutions failures when looking up a hostname or a URi.
segment.target: Name resolutions failures when looking up a hostname or a URi.

segment.source: Loss or change in network connectivity.
segment.target: Loss or change in network connectivity.

segment.source: Network connection failures using sockets or the HTTP client APIs.
segment.target: Network connection failures using sockets or the HTTP client APIs.

segment.source: Network server or remote endpoint errors.
segment.target: Network server or remote endpoint errors.

segment.source: Miscellaneous networking errors.
segment.target: Miscellaneous networking errors.

segment.source: Exceptions from network errors (for example, loss or change of connectivity, connection failures, and server failures) can happen at any time.
segment.target: Exceptions from network errors (for example, loss or change of connectivity, connection failures, and server failures) can happen at any time.

segment.source: These errors result in exceptions being thrown.
segment.target: These errors result in exceptions being thrown.

segment.source: If an exception is not handled by your app, it can cause your entire app to be terminated by the runtime.
segment.target: If an exception is not handled by your app, it can cause your entire app to be terminated by the runtime.

segment.source: You must write code to handle exceptions when you call most asynchronous network methods.
segment.target: You must write code to handle exceptions when you call most asynchronous network methods.

segment.source: Sometimes, when an exception occurs, a network method can be retried as a way to resolve the problem.
segment.target: Sometimes, when an exception occurs, a network method can be retried as a way to resolve the problem.

segment.source: Other times, your app may need to plan to continue without network connectivity using previously cached data.
segment.target: Other times, your app may need to plan to continue without network connectivity using previously cached data.

segment.source: Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps generally throw a single exception.
segment.target: Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps generally throw a single exception.

segment.source: Your exception handler can retrieve more detailed information about the cause of the exception to better understand the failure and make appropriate decisions.
segment.target: Your exception handler can retrieve more detailed information about the cause of the exception to better understand the failure and make appropriate decisions.

segment.source: When an exception occurs in a DirectX game that is a UWP app, the HRESULT value for the cause of the error can be retrieved.
segment.target: When an exception occurs in a DirectX game that is a UWP app, the HRESULT value for the cause of the error can be retrieved.

segment.source: The Winerror.h include file contains a large list of possible HRESULT values that includes network errors.
segment.target: The Winerror.h include file contains a large list of possible HRESULT values that includes network errors.

segment.source: The networking APIs support different methods for retrieving this detailed information about the cause of an exception.
segment.target: The networking APIs support different methods for retrieving this detailed information about the cause of an exception.

segment.source: A method to retrieve the HRESULT value of the error that caused the exception.
segment.target: A method to retrieve the HRESULT value of the error that caused the exception.

segment.source: The possible list of potential HRESULT values is large and unspecified.
segment.target: The possible list of potential HRESULT values is large and unspecified.

segment.source: The HRESULT value can be retrieved when using any of the networking APIs.
segment.target: The HRESULT value can be retrieved when using any of the networking APIs.

segment.source: A helper method that converts the HRESULT value to an enumeration value.
segment.target: A helper method that converts the HRESULT value to an enumeration value.

segment.source: The list of possible enumeration values is specified and relatively small.
segment.target: The list of possible enumeration values is specified and relatively small.

segment.source: A helper method is available for the socket classes in the Windows::Networking::Sockets.
segment.target: A helper method is available for the socket classes in the Windows::Networking::Sockets.

segment.source: Exceptions in Windows.Networking.Sockets
segment.target: Exceptions in Windows.Networking.Sockets

segment.source: The constructor for the HostName class used with sockets can throw an exception if the string passed is not a valid hostname (contains characters that are not allowed in a host name).
segment.target: The constructor for the HostName class used with sockets can throw an exception if the string passed is not a valid hostname (contains characters that are not allowed in a host name).

segment.source: If an app gets input from the user for the HostName for a peer connection for gaming, the constructor should be in a try/catch block.
segment.target: If an app gets input from the user for the HostName for a peer connection for gaming, the constructor should be in a try/catch block.

segment.source: If an exception is thrown, the app can notify the user and request a new hostname.
segment.target: If an exception is thrown, the app can notify the user and request a new hostname.

segment.source: Add code to validate a string for a hostname from the user
segment.target: Add code to validate a string for a hostname from the user

segment.source: The Windows.Networking.Sockets namespace has convenient helper methods and enumerations for handling errors when using sockets.
segment.target: The Windows.Networking.Sockets namespace has convenient helper methods and enumerations for handling errors when using sockets.

segment.source: This can be useful for handling specific network exceptions differently in your app.
segment.target: This can be useful for handling specific network exceptions differently in your app.

segment.source: An error encountered on DatagramSocket, StreamSocket, or StreamSocketListener operation results in an exception being thrown.
segment.target: An error encountered on DatagramSocket, StreamSocket, or StreamSocketListener operation results in an exception being thrown.

segment.source: The cause of the exception is an error value represented as an HRESULT value.
segment.target: The cause of the exception is an error value represented as an HRESULT value.

segment.source: The SocketError.GetStatus method is used to convert a network error from a socket operation to a SocketErrorStatus enumeration value.
segment.target: The SocketError.GetStatus method is used to convert a network error from a socket operation to a SocketErrorStatus enumeration value.

segment.source: Most of the SocketErrorStatus enumeration values correspond to an error returned by the native Windows sockets operation.
segment.target: Most of the SocketErrorStatus enumeration values correspond to an error returned by the native Windows sockets operation.

segment.source: An app can filter on specific SocketErrorStatus enumeration values to modify app behavior depending on the cause of the exception.
segment.target: An app can filter on specific SocketErrorStatus enumeration values to modify app behavior depending on the cause of the exception.

segment.source: For parameter validation errors, an app can also use the HRESULT from the exception to learn more detailed information about the error that caused the exception.
segment.target: For parameter validation errors, an app can also use the HRESULT from the exception to learn more detailed information about the error that caused the exception.

segment.source: Possible HRESULT values are listed in the Winerror.h header file.
segment.target: Possible HRESULT values are listed in the Winerror.h header file.

segment.source: For most parameter validation errors, the HRESULT returned is E\_INVALIDARG.
segment.target: For most parameter validation errors, the HRESULT returned is E\_INVALIDARG.

segment.source: Add code to handle exceptions when trying to make a stream socket connection
segment.target: Add code to handle exceptions when trying to make a stream socket connection

segment.source: Exceptions in Windows.Web.Http
segment.target: Exceptions in Windows.Web.Http

segment.source: The constructor for the Windows::Foundation::Uri class used with Windows::Web::Http::HttpClient can throw an exception if the string passed is not a valid URI (contains characters that are not allowed in a URI).
segment.target: The constructor for the Windows::Foundation::Uri class used with Windows::Web::Http::HttpClient can throw an exception if the string passed is not a valid URI (contains characters that are not allowed in a URI).

segment.source: In C++, there is no method to try and parse a string to a URI.
segment.target: In C++, there is no method to try and parse a string to a URI.

segment.source: If an app gets input from the user for the Windows::Foundation::Uri, the constructor should be in a try/catch block.
segment.target: If an app gets input from the user for the Windows::Foundation::Uri, the constructor should be in a try/catch block.

segment.source: If an exception is thrown, the app can notify the user and request a new URI.
segment.target: If an exception is thrown, the app can notify the user and request a new URI.

segment.source: Your app should also check that the scheme in the URI is HTTP or HTTPS since these are the only schemes supported by the Windows::Web::Http::HttpClient.
segment.target: Your app should also check that the scheme in the URI is HTTP or HTTPS since these are the only schemes supported by the Windows::Web::Http::HttpClient.

segment.source: Add code to validate a string for a URI from the user
segment.target: Add code to validate a string for a URI from the user

segment.source: The Windows::Web::Http namespace lacks a convenience function.
segment.target: The Windows::Web::Http namespace lacks a convenience function.

segment.source: So, an app using HttpClient and other classes in this namespace needs to use the HRESULT value.
segment.target: So, an app using HttpClient and other classes in this namespace needs to use the HRESULT value.

segment.source: In apps using C++, the Platform::Exception represents an error during app execution when an exception occurs.
segment.target: In apps using C++, the Platform::Exception represents an error during app execution when an exception occurs.

segment.source: The Platform::Exception::HResult property returns the HRESULT assigned to the specific exception.
segment.target: The Platform::Exception::HResult property returns the HRESULT assigned to the specific exception.

segment.source: The Platform::Exception::Message property returns the system-provided string that is associated with the HRESULT value.
segment.target: The Platform::Exception::Message property returns the system-provided string that is associated with the HRESULT value.

segment.source: Possible HRESULT values are listed in the Winerror.h header file.
segment.target: Possible HRESULT values are listed in the Winerror.h header file.

segment.source: An app can filter on specific HRESULT values to modify app behavior depending on the cause of the exception.
segment.target: An app can filter on specific HRESULT values to modify app behavior depending on the cause of the exception.

segment.source: For most parameter validation errors, the HRESULT returned is E\_INVALIDARG.
segment.target: For most parameter validation errors, the HRESULT returned is E\_INVALIDARG.

segment.source: For some illegal method calls, the HRESULT returned is E\_ILLEGAL\_METHOD\_CALL.
segment.target: For some illegal method calls, the HRESULT returned is E\_ILLEGAL\_METHOD\_CALL.

segment.source: Add code to handle exceptions when trying to use HttpClient to connect to an HTTP server
segment.target: Add code to handle exceptions when trying to use HttpClient to connect to an HTTP server
